qas.question: What causes the directionality of DNA strands?

answers.text: the chemical composition of the pentose residues of the bases

qas.question: What is known as the 3' end?

answers.text: an exposed hydroxyl group on the deoxyribose

qas.question: What is known as the 5' end?
What type of synthesis occurs in the 5'→3' direction?
Why does DNA replication and transcription occur in the 5'→3' direction?

answers.text: because new nucleotides are added via a dehydration reaction that uses the exposed 3' hydroxyl as a nucleophile

context: Due to <a0_0>the chemical composition of the pentose residues of the bases<a0_0/>, DNA strands have directionality. One end of a DNA polymer contains <a1_0>an exposed hydroxyl group on the deoxyribose<a1_0/>; this is known as the 3' end of the molecule. The other end contains <a2_0>an exposed phosphate group<a2_0/>; this is the 5' end. The two strands of a double-helix run in opposite directions. <a3_0>Nucleic acid synthesis<a3_0/>, including DNA replication and transcription occurs in the 5'→3' direction, <a4_0>because new nucleotides are added via a dehydration reaction that uses the exposed 3' hydroxyl as a nucleophile<a4_0/>.:27.2
